citeinfo.origin: Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, Government of Alberta
citeinfo.title: Alberta CWCS Merged Wetland Inventory

pubinfo.publish: Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, Government of Alberta

descript.abstract:
This dataset depicts wetlands within the province of Alberta, Canada for the period 1998 to 2012 classified to the Canadian Wetland Classification System (CWCS) class level (marsh, open water, bog, fen and swamp). This layer is a merged product of component wetland inventories with differing specifications on how wetlands were captured and classified. Because some of the component wetland inventories used different wetland classification systems the inventories were reclassified to the CWCS.
The component wetland inventory systems are described below.
Ducks Unlimited Canada (DUC)-Boreal Enhanced Wetland Classification System (EWC): Landsat 5 and 7 ETM imagery were used to capture and classify wetlands to DUC's EWC system. The classification system contains a class level, analogous to the CWCS class level, which is subdivided to the EWC minor level which contains information on the dominant vegetation. An accuracy assessment derived from field sites is available for all inventories. The minimum mapping unit of the inventory is 1 ha. Data is distributed by Ducks Unlimited Canada - Western Boreal Office as described in the Contact/Distribution sections of the metadata.
Landsat-Canadian Wetland Classification System (CWCS): Landsat 7 ETM imagery was used to capture and classify wetlands to the CWCS class level. The minimum mapping unit of the inventory is 1 ha. Data is distributed by Environment and Sustainable Resource Development as described in the Contact/Distribution sections of the metadata.
SPOT (Systeme Pour l'Observation de la Terre) Grassland Vegetation Inventory (GVI) Lentic Classification: SPOT 5 MS imagery was used to capture and classify wetlands to Alberta Sustainable Resource Developments (ASRD) GVI standard. The GVI classifies lentic wetlands using a modified Stewart and Kantrud approach which identifies wetland site types and permanence. The GVI lentic wetlands were reclassified to the CWCS major level. The minimum mapping unit of the inventory is 0.2 ha. Data is distributed by Environment and Sustainable Resource Development. Data is distributed by Environment and Sustainable Resource Development as described in the Contact/Distribution sections of the metadata.
High-Resolution: 1:15,000 to 1:30,000 air photography was used to capture and classify wetlands to a DUC custom system and the CWCS. The DUC custom wetlands were reclassified to the CWCS major level using a model developed by DUC. The minimum mapping unit of the inventory is 0.04 ha. Data is distributed by Environment and Sustainable Resource Development as described in the Contact/Distribution sections of the metadata.
descript.purpose: To depict the current coverage of wetlands within Alberta at the regional and provincial scales using the best available information.
descript.supplinf: This dataset is an amalgamation of wetland inventories captured at different times using different inventory systems and as a result, has limitations in terms of image resolution and analysis above the original project boundary. Care should be taken when comparing or using portions of this data composed of wetland features captured using different inventory methods. As noted in the metadata, the resolution quality of the SPOT data is coarse, the boreal EWC data, medium and the high resolution inventory has fine resolution. The wetland inventory dataset is not intended to replace site specific or local information to describe wetland type, area and location. For questions related to planning or operations near wetlands, users of this information are directed to contact the appropriate Alberta Environment and Water or Alberta Sustainable Resource Development regional office.

idinfo.accconst: Access to this data is unrestricted.
idinfo.useconst: Redistribution of this data in whole or in part, whether alone or as part of a value added product, is not permitted without the prior written authorisation of Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development. Use of the data shall not be construed as an endorsement by the 'Government of Alberta'.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.2 (Build 3790) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

attracc.attraccr: Classification accuracies were determined for the DUC - Boreal, SPOT and Landsat inventory systems. Reports exist for each system and can be requested by contacting Dave Junor (dave.junor@gov.ab.ca). When requesting a report please cite the inventory system type and extent.

qattracc.attracce: Classification accuracies for the DUC - Boreal, SPOT and Landsat inventories are available.

qhorizpa.horizpav: 20 meters from the ground control data at 90% confidence.
qhorizpa.horizpae: SPOT: Spatial accuracy of the SPOT5 image data is assessed by IUNCTUS Geomatics, the contracting company responsible for the delivery of SPOT5 image data. Technicians are trained to quantify the RMSE based on control data. The technicians also visually ensure that imagery align with ground control datasets used and other overlapping imagery.

DUC - Boreal and Landsat: Individual satellite imagery was orthorectified to USGS Level 1 standards. Using the methodology from the U.S. Federal Geospatial Data Committee (FGDC) National Standard for Spatial Data Accuracy (NSSDA) the positional error for each image was determined and the average across all images reported.
Hi - Resolution: Wetland boundaries digitized from 1:15,000 to 1:30,000 scale orthophotos.

procstep.procdesc: DUC - Boreal Landsat imagery was classified to the CWCS or EWC.
SPOT - South SPOT imagery was classified to the Grassland Vegetation Inventory (GVI) system.
SPOT - Central SPOT imagery was classified to the Grassland Vegetation Inventory (GVI) system.
Landsat imagery was classified to the CWCS.
High - Resolution Orthophotos were acquired and the wetlands digitized and classified.
Wetland Inventories converted to vector and merged into a single layer.

cntperp.cntorg: Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, Government of Alberta

procstep.procdesc: Spot and the High - Resolution wetland inventories were reclassified to the CWCS.

cntperp.cntorg: Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, Government of Alberta

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

edom.edomvd: Peat-covered wetlands (peatlands), in which the vegetation shows the effects of a high water table and a general lack of nutrients. The bog surface is often raised relative to the surrounding landscape and isolated from mineralized soil waters. The surface waters of bogs are strongly acid and the upper peat layers are generally nutrient poor. At least 40cm of peat are present. The plant community is dominated by cushion-forming Sphagnum mosses (peat mosses), ericaceous shrubs and black spruce trees.
edom.edomvds: National Wetlands Working Group. 1997. The Canadian Wetland Classification System, 2nd Edition. Warner, B.G. and C.D.A. Rubec (eds.), Wetlands Research Centre, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada. 68 p.

edom.edomvd: Peatlands characterized by a high water table, but with very slow internal drainage by seepage. Similar to bogs, the surface water in fens is also generally nutrient poor and the peat layer is at least 40 cm thick. The vegetation in fens usually reflects the water quality and quantity available, resulting in three basic types: graminoid fens without trees or shrubs, shrub fens, and treed fens. Dominant plants include black spruce, tamarack, sedges, grasses, and various mosses.
edom.edomvds: National Wetlands Working Group. 1997. The Canadian Wetland Classification System, 2nd Edition. Warner, B.G. and C.D.A. Rubec (eds.), Wetlands Research Centre, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada. 68 p.

edom.edomvd: Wetlands that are periodically inundated by standing or slowly moving water and hence are rich in nutrients. Marshes are mainly wet, mineral-soil areas, but shallow, well-decomposed peat may be present. Marshes are subject to a gravitational water table, but water remains within the rooting zone of plants for most of the growing season. They are characterized by an emergent vegetation of reeds, rushes or sedges and the absence of woody vegetation.
edom.edomvds: National Wetlands Working Group. 1997. The Canadian Wetland Classification System, 2nd Edition. Warner, B.G. and C.D.A. Rubec (eds.), Wetlands Research Centre, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada. 68 p.

edom.edomvd: Wetlands where standing or gently moving waters occur seasonally or persist for long periods, leaving the subsurface continuously waterlogged. The water may also be present as a subsurface flow of mineralized water. The water table may drop seasonally below the rooting zone of the vegetation, creating aerated conditions at the surface. Their substrate consists of mixtures of mineral and organic materials, and peat deposited may be present. The vegetation may consist of dense coniferous or deciduous forest, or tall shrub thickets.
edom.edomvds: National Wetlands Working Group. 1997. The Canadian Wetland Classification System, 2nd Edition. Warner, B.G. and C.D.A. Rubec (eds.), Wetlands Research Centre, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada. 68 p.

edom.edomvd: Known as ponds or sloughs, are relatively small bodies of standing water, representing a transition stage between lakes and marshes. The surface waters impart an open aspect, free of emergent vegetation, but floating, rooted, aquatic macrophytes may be present. The depth of water is usually less than 2 m in mid-summer.
edom.edomvds: National Wetlands Working Group. 1997. The Canadian Wetland Classification System, 2nd Edition. Warner, B.G. and C.D.A. Rubec (eds.), Wetlands Research Centre, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada. 68 p.

attr.attrdef: The type of imagery and classification system used to produce the wetland inventory

edom.edomvd: A wetland inventory derived from landsat satellite imagery which classifies wetlands using the DUC Enhanced Wetland Classification System.
A SPOT derived wetland inventory which uses SRD's GVI system to classify wetlands.
edom.edomvds: Alberta Terrestrial Imaging Centre (ATIC) for southern coverage and Silvatech for central area.

edom.edomvd: A landsat derived wetland inventory that uses the Canadian Wetlands Classification System (CWCS) to classify wetlands.
A wetland inventory derived form 1:15,000 to 1:30,000 scale orthophotos, using heads-up digitizing to capture wetlands.

attr.attrdef: The project area within AB for which the wetland inventory was created.
The level of detail at which wetlands are classified and boundaries captured.

edom.edomvd: Wetlands captured and classified by an interpreter using stereoscopic air photography. Appropriate sclae of use is at the site level and above.

Wetlands captured and classified using the Boreal Plains Enhanced field calibrated methodology. Appropriate sclae of use is at the watershed basin level and above. Can be used for some site work but resolution limits detection of smaller wetlands.
Wetlands captured and classified using SPOT and Landsat satellite imagery. Appropriate scale of use is at the regional planning level.

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.
